channel.title: Why does Kicksecure requires a user with username user?
channel.description: Why does Kicksecure requires a user with username user rather then anything else? I want to create a separate Kicksecure secure hardened and no-login user(like `www-data` for Apache) to run Containers(podman, Docker or LXC), Proxmox or any other software. The `user` already have too much privileges and I want to avoid from using it. What should I do?

item.title: Why does Kicksecure requires a user with username user?
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
Patrick Schleizer:

security-misc sets up root access restrictions. Its preinst script requires that there is some user (not hardcoded to user user) that is member of the sudo group. Otherwise you’d be locked out.

This applies to all of the users in group sudo right?

Yes. Any user name is acceptable.

Patrick Schleizer:

What privileges? And if so, why not remove these?

Which account are you going to use to run sudo?

I want to use another user without any privileges or can’t even login to run containers, I will be using user for administration.

Ok.

item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
Why does Kicksecure requires a user with username user rather then anything else?

The premise that Kicksecure requires that might be wrong. What makes you think it does?

Hardcoding user names to user user has been avoided in the Kicksecure source code as much as possible.

security-misc sets up root access restrictions. Its preinst script requires that there is some user (not hardcoded to user user) that is member of the sudo group. Otherwise you’d be locked out.

What should I do?

  • Disable login for user user.
  • Try delete user user.
  • Search the Source Code.
